technologies.name: Laravel
technologies.opinion: In terms of building backends and server-rendered web apps, Laravel is my favorite framework to use. It's the first web framework I learned and it's the reason I love developing full-stack applications, especially now that Laravel has a very good ecosystem and libraries that really makes my life easy.

technologies.name: Vue.js
technologies.opinion: I think Vue is the UI framework that makes the most sense to me. Especially the Composition API and the `<script setup>` syntax. It's very simple to use, easy to learn, scalable, and has great community support.

technologies.name: Inertia.js
technologies.opinion: Inertia is one of the technologies that blew my mind. When I first started using Laravel, I mainly use it to build APIs that my frontend applications consume. It's quite a pain-in-the ass to maintain two separate repos. But with Inertia, it's very easy to build powerful full-stack apps. I can just use Laravel and Vue without any hassle.

technologies.name: Tailwind CSS
technologies.opinion: I love CSS, but Tailwind just makes writing styles fun and easy. It's my go-to CSS framework when I need to build some good-looking interfaces. I can't imagine not using Tailwind in my projects.

technologies.name: MySQL
technologies.opinion: In terms of databases, MySQL is always my first choice. As much as I love using NoSQL databases, it's still much better to plan the schema and build databases using Relational Databases.

technologies.name: TypeScript
technologies.opinion: As much as I love vanilla JavaScript, I can't go back to it once I learned TypeScript. I believe it's a must-have for any developer who wants to build a scalable web application.

technologies.name: PHP
technologies.opinion: I think PHP is overly hated these days. But in reality, modern PHP is a very powerful language, and in my opinion, building backends in PHP is a lot more intuitive than building backends in JavaScript.

technologies.name: Node.js
technologies.opinion: It's the most popular JavaScript runtime. It's a must-have for full-stack developers.

technologies.name: Bun
technologies.opinion: I've been using Bun for quite some time. It's much faster to work with than Node, especially when using its built in package manager. I also love that TypeScript works out of the box.

technologies.name: Express
technologies.opinion: Express is my most used library in creating JavaScript backends. It's very simple to use.

technologies.name: Astro
technologies.opinion: Astro is my go-to technology in terms of developing static websites. It has great performance and great community support. It also integrates well with all popular frameworks and libraries if I want to have some interactivity. In fact, this website is built with Astro.

technologies.name: React
technologies.opinion: At first, I hate React because of its syntax. But as I use it in my work, I understand the strengths and advantages of it. The ecosystem is top-notch. Integrations with third-party libraries are very well supported.

technologies.name: React Native
technologies.opinion: My go-to technology when building mobile apps. It's very easy to develop cross-platform apps that are truly native, and because I'm a web developer, I feel right at home with it.

technologies.name: MongoDB
technologies.opinion: MongoDB is a great tool to quickly store data. It's very powerful and has great integrations with JavaScript libraries and frameworks.

technologies.name: Storyblok
technologies.opinion: I think Storyblok is one of the best CMS I've used. It's a great way to build content and a great way to build an ecosystem of plugins.

technologies.name: Git
technologies.opinion: Must-have for version control. Nuffsaid.

technologies.name: Docker
technologies.opinion: Setting up development environment and production infrastructure has never been easier with Docker. I'm in love with this technology because I literally can do whatever I want with it. It's a great skillset to have especially in CI/CD pipelines and automations.

technologies.name: CodeIgniter
technologies.opinion: I used CodeIgniter in some of the legacy projects in my company. Not a big fan of it but it's the framework most of our projects was built with and it gets the job done.

technologies.name: Nuxt.js
technologies.opinion: Since I love using Vue, I'm also enjoying using Nuxt. It's just the best of both worlds. I'm looking forward to use it in my future projects.

technologies.name: Next.js
technologies.opinion: The most popular framework in the JavaScript ecosystem. Haven't used it (cuz Vue is life) but I'm excited to try it out.

technologies.name: Svelte
technologies.opinion: Similar with Vue, I like the simplicity of the syntax of Svelte. I tried using it and the developer experience is amazing. The ecosystem is not that good since it's kinda new but I think in a few years it will be great.

technologies.name: PostgreSQL
technologies.opinion: Just like MySQL, I like using Postgres. Unfortunately, it's not the go-to database in my work (they love MySQL), but I used it on my personal projects.

technologies.name: Bootstrap
technologies.opinion: My first CSS framework I used earlier in my career. It's the CSS framework that my professional projects mostly use. It gets the job done but I'm not a fan of it, I prefer styling things with full control like Tailwind.
